title: Quiz 1: Medical-Surgical Nursing (Jan 2025 FQE)
topicName: Medical Surgical Nursing FQE PastPapers Collection
description: Full conversion of the January 2025 FQE Paper 1 covering electrolytes, respiratory, cardiovascular, and perioperative nursing.

questions.question: The plasma membrane of a cell presents a barrier to the movement of electrolytes through it. The one characteristic for this barrier is:

options.text: There are no channels in the membrane for the passage of electrolytes.
Electrolytes are not soluble in the lipid of the membrane.
Electrolytes are too large to pass through membrane channels.
Membrane proteins electrically repel charged particles.

questions.explanation: The plasma membrane is composed primarily of a phospholipid bilayer, which has a hydrophobic (water-fearing) interior. Electrolytes are charged ions (hydrophilic) and cannot pass through this non-polar lipid barrier without assistance (channels/carriers).
questions.hint: Think about the solubility of charged ions in fat (lipids).

questions.question: The blood PH is constantly maintained by buffer systems. The reaction of the blood's phosphate buffer when a hydrogen ion is encountered is:

options.text: HPO4(2-) destroys the hydrogen ion and becomes H2PO4(-) and blood pH decreases very slightly
H2PO4(-) destroys the hydrogen ion and becomes HPO4(2-) and blood pH decreases very slightly
HPO4(2-) destroys the hydrogen ion and becomes H2PO4(-) and blood pH increases very slightly
H2PO4(-) destroys the hydrogen ion and becomes HPO4(2-) and blood pH increases very slightly

questions.explanation: The monohydrogen phosphate ion (HPO4 2-) acts as a weak base. When it encounters a strong acid (H+), it accepts the proton to form dihydrogen phosphate (H2PO4 -), a weak acid. This prevents a drastic pH drop, though a very slight decrease still occurs.
questions.hint: The buffer accepts the acid (H+) to minimize pH change.

questions.question: The ovarian cycle consists of several phases that occur in a specific sequence, controlled by hormonal changes. These phases include:

options.text: Menarche, menstrual cycle, menopause
Luteal, follicular and proliferative
Follicular, ovulation and the luteal
Menses, proliferative and secretory

questions.explanation: The ovarian cycle phases are: 1. Follicular phase (egg maturation), 2. Ovulation (release), 3. Luteal phase (corpus luteum). Option D refers to the uterine (endometrial) cycle.
questions.hint: Focus on the ovary's activity, not the uterus.

questions.question: When giving an intramuscular (IM) injection using the Z-track technique, the nurse should:

options.text: Use a needle at least 1-inch long.
Apply pressure to the injection site.
Inject the medication quickly, and steadily withdraw the needle.
Do not massage the site because it may cause irritation.

questions.explanation: The Z-track method is used to seal medication in the muscle. Massaging can force the medication back into the subcutaneous tissue, causing irritation or staining. Injection should be slow (10 sec/ml), not quick.
questions.hint: Massaging defeats the purpose of sealing the track.

questions.question: If a child with asthma is not rinsing their mouth after using a glucocorticoid inhaler, a common symptom to look for is:

options.text: Enlarged tonsils
Grey membrane in the throat
Persistent cough
White patches in mouth

questions.explanation: Inhaled corticosteroids can cause oral candidiasis (thrush), presenting as white patches, due to local immunosuppression in the mouth.
questions.hint: This is a fungal infection side effect.

questions.question: Mrs. R, an overweight, highly stressed 50-year-old executive, is being discharged from the hospital after undergoing coronary bypass surgery. The goal in the affective domain you would develop for her care is:

options.text: By the end of 2 hours, the patient will list three benefits of daily exercise.
By the end of 2 hours, the patient will correctly demonstrate breathing techniques to reduce stress.
By the end of 2 hours, the patient will value his health sufficiently to reduce the cholesterol in his diet.
By the end of 2 hours, the patient will be able to plan healthy weekly menus.

questions.explanation: The affective domain relates to feelings, values, and attitudes. 'Valuing' health (Option C) is affective. 'Listing' (A) and 'Planning' (D) are cognitive. 'Demonstrating' (B) is psychomotor.
questions.hint: Look for the option dealing with values, feelings, or attitudes.

questions.question: You are teaching a junior student on breath sounds. Which of the following should a junior student report to you about vesicular breath sounds on return demonstration?

options.text: They are high-pitched, harsh sounds, with expiration being longer than inspiration.
They are noisy, strenuous respirations.
They are high-pitched sounds heard on inspiration when there is a narrowing of the upper airway.
They are soft, low-pitched sounds heard best over the base of the lungs with inspiration longer than expiration

questions.explanation: Vesicular sounds are normal breath sounds: soft, low-pitched, breezy, heard over most lung fields, with inspiration lasting longer than expiration.
questions.hint: These are the normal sounds heard over the majority of the lungs.

questions.question: In medical asepsis, areas are considered contaminated if they come into contact with any object or surface that is not sterile.
questions.explanation: This describes SURGICAL asepsis (sterile technique). In medical asepsis (clean technique), areas are contaminated if they bear pathogens (are 'dirty'), not just if they touch something non-sterile.
questions.hint: Distinguish between 'clean' technique and 'sterile' technique.

questions.question: Mr. P is an obese 62-year-old man scheduled for heart surgery. The surgical risks related to obesity that should be considered when performing an assessment for this patient include:

options.text: Delayed wound healing and wound infection
Alterations in fluid and electrolyte balance
Respiratory distress
Hemorrhage

questions.explanation: Adipose tissue is relatively avascular, meaning it has poor blood supply. This impairs the delivery of oxygen and nutrients needed for healing, increasing the risk of infection and dehiscence.
questions.hint: Fatty tissue has poor blood supply.

questions.question: The nursing diagnosis of 'Risk for Injury' following a stapedectomy is based on several factors associated with the surgery and its potential complications. The nurse identifies this risk due to:

options.text: Nystagmus may result from perilymph disturbances caused by surgery.
Stimulation of the labyrinth during surgery may cause vertigo and loss of balance.
Blowing the nose or coughing may precipitate dislodgement of the tympanic graft.
Postoperative tinnitus may decrease the patient's awareness of environmental hazards.

questions.explanation: Stapedectomy involves surgery on the middle ear near the labyrinth (inner ear) which controls balance. Stimulation causes vertigo, creating a high risk for falls/injury.
questions.hint: The surgery is near the inner ear balance center.

questions.question: Glaucoma is a group of eye conditions that can lead to optic nerve damage and vision loss. The important health promotion nursing intervention for a middle-aged adult related to glaucoma would be:

options.text: Teach individuals at risk for glaucoma about early signs and symptoms of the disease.
Prepare patients with glaucoma for lifestyle changes necessary to adapt to eventual blindness.
Promote measurements of intraocular pressure every 2 to 4 years for early detection and treatment of glaucoma.
Inform patients that glaucoma is curable if eye medications are administered before visual impairment has occurred.

questions.explanation: Glaucoma is often asymptomatic in early stages. Regular screening (tonometry) is the most effective way to detect increased pressure before irreversible damage occurs.
questions.hint: Glaucoma is often called the 'silent thief of sight' because it has few early symptoms.

questions.question: A patient is admitted to the emergency department with a wood splinter imbedded in the right eye. The priority intervention by the nurse would be:

options.text: Irrigate the eye with a large amount of sterile saline.
Carefully remove the splinter with a pair of sterile forceps.
Cover the eye with a dry sterile patch and a protective shield.
Apply light pressure on the closed eye to prevent bleeding

questions.explanation: For impaled objects, the priority is to stabilize the object to prevent further injury. Never remove the object, never apply pressure, and do not irrigate as it may cause movement.
questions.hint: Stabilize, do not manipulate.

questions.question: The nurse receives an evening report on a patient who underwent posterior nasal packing for epistaxis earlier in the day. The priority patient assessment the nurse should pay attention to is:

options.text: Patient's temperature
Level of the patient's pain
Drainage on the nasal dressing
Oxygen saturation by pulse oximetry

questions.explanation: Posterior packing can slip and obstruct the airway, and it can also cause reflex hypoventilation (nasopulmonary reflex), leading to hypoxia. Airway/Breathing is the priority.
questions.hint: Remember ABCs: Airway/Breathing first.

questions.question: A newly posted intern is considering either endotracheal or tracheostomy in the management of a patient with long term upper airway obstruction. You will inform him that an advantage of a tracheostomy over an endotracheal (ET) tube is:

options.text: A tracheostomy is safer to perform in an emergency.
An ET tube has a higher risk of tracheal pressure necrosis.
A tracheostomy tube allows for more comfort and mobility.
An ET tube is more likely to lead to lower respiratory tract infection.

questions.explanation: Tracheostomies bypass the mouth/nose, allowing for better oral care, comfort, potential for speech, and mobility compared to an ET tube which is uncomfortable and requires sedation.
questions.hint: Think about long-term comfort and the ability to eat/speak.

questions.question: To determine whether a tension pneumothorax is developing in a patient with chest trauma, the confirmatory sign the nurse should assess for is:

options.text: Dull percussion sounds on the injured side
Severe respiratory distress and tracheal deviation
Muffled and distant heart sounds with decreasing blood pressure
Decreased movement and diminished breath sounds on the affected side

questions.explanation: The hallmark of tension pneumothorax is the buildup of pressure that shifts the mediastinum, causing tracheal deviation away from the affected side and severe distress.
questions.hint: Look for a sign indicating mediastinal shift.

questions.question: A patient is scheduled for bone marrow examination. The most appropriate teaching a nurse should give to the patient regarding the procedure is:

options.text: The procedure will be done under general anesthesia because it is so painful.
The patient will not have any pain after the area at the puncture site is anesthetized.
The patient will experience a brief, very sharp pain during aspiration of the bone marrow.
There will be no pain during the procedure, but an ache will be present several days afterward.

questions.explanation: Local anesthesia numbs the skin/periosteum but cannot numb the inside of the bone. Aspiration creates negative pressure, causing a distinct, sharp pain for a few seconds.
questions.hint: The suctioning part of the procedure causes a specific sensation.

questions.question: A 20-yr-old female patient is in the emergency department for anorexia and fatigue management. She takes phenytoin for a seizure disorder and oral contraceptives. For which type of anemia is this patient most at risk of:

options.text: Aplastic anemia
Hemolytic anemia
Iron-deficiency anemia
Folic acid deficiency anemia

questions.explanation: Phenytoin (Dilantin) interferes with folic acid absorption/metabolism, commonly leading to megaloblastic (folic acid deficiency) anemia.
questions.hint: Phenytoin affects B-vitamin levels.

questions.question: A patient has been having chest pain for the last two weeks. The assessment findings that will differentiate unstable angina from an myocardial infarction is:

options.text: ECG changes present at the onset of the pain
A chest x-ray indicating left ventricular hypertrophy
Serum troponin levels increased 4 to 6 hours after the onset
Creatine kinase MB (CK-MB) elevations that peak 6 hours after the pain

questions.explanation: Myocardial Infarction involves cell death, releasing cardiac markers (Troponin). Unstable angina involves ischemia without enough cell death to elevate enzymes. Troponin is the specific marker.
questions.hint: Look for the marker of cardiac muscle death.

questions.question: In a patient experiencing ventricular fibrillation (VF), the rationale for using cardiac defibrillation is to:

options.text: Enhance repolarization and relaxation of ventricular myocardial cells
Provide an electrical impulse that stimulates normal myocardial contractions
Depolarize the cells of the myocardium to allow the SA node to resume pacemaker function
Deliver an electrical impulse to the heart at the time of ventricular contraction to convert the heart to a sinus rhythm

questions.explanation: Defibrillation delivers a massive shock that simultaneously depolarizes all myocardial cells, stopping the chaotic rhythm (VF) and allowing the natural pacemaker (SA node) to take over.
questions.hint: It acts like a 'reset' button for the heart's electricity.

questions.question: Patient N is diagnosed with infective endocarditis. To diagnose Janeway's lesions, what physical presentations would be a pointer:

options.text: Hemorrhagic retinal lesions
Black longitudinal streaks in nail beds
Painful red or purple lesions on fingers or toes
Flat, red, painless spots on the palm of hands and soles of feet

questions.explanation: Janeway lesions are non-tender, hemorrhagic lesions on palms/soles. Osler nodes (C) are painful. Roth spots (A) are in eyes.
questions.hint: Janeway lesions are painless and on palms/soles.

questions.question: A patient with a gastric outlet obstruction has been treated with Nasogastric decompression. After the first 24 hours, the patient develops nausea and increased upper abdominal bowel sounds. The priority action by the nurse would be:

options.text: Check the patency of the nasogastric tube.
Place the patient in a recumbent position.
Assess the patient's vital signs and circulatory status.
Encourage the patient to deep breath and consciously relax.

questions.explanation: Nausea and distension/sounds in a patient with an NGT suggest the tube is blocked and not draining. Checking patency restores decompression.
questions.hint: If the drain isn't draining, the stomach fills up again.

questions.question: A patient has persistent and continuous pain at McBurney's point. The nursing assessment reveals rebound tenderness and muscle guarding. The nursing interventions for this patient includes:

options.text: Laxatives to move the constipated bowel
Nil per oral status in preparation for possible appendectomy
Parenteral fluids and high dose antibiotic therapy for 6 hours
Nasogastric tube inserted to decompress the stomach and prevent aspiration

questions.explanation: Signs point to Appendicitis. Surgery is likely. NPO status is crucial for safe anesthesia. Laxatives (A) are contraindicated as they can cause rupture.
questions.hint: This is a surgical emergency; keep the stomach empty.

questions.question: You are caring for a patient on fluid therapy. Which urine specific gravity value would indicate the patient is receiving excessive IV fluid therapy?
questions.explanation: Normal SG is 1.005-1.030. A low SG (1.002) indicates very dilute urine, which is a sign of fluid overload/overhydration as the kidneys try to dump excess water.
questions.hint: Overhydration leads to very dilute urine (low number).

questions.question: Following a renal biopsy, the nurse's priority intervention is:

options.text: Offer warm sitz baths to relieve discomfort.
Test urine for microscopic bleeding with a dipstick.
Expect the patient to experience burning on urination.
Monitor the patient for symptoms of a urinary infection.

questions.explanation: The kidney is highly vascular. Hemorrhage is the main risk. Testing urine for blood helps detect internal bleeding early.
questions.hint: The kidney bleeds easily.

questions.question: A patient has a right ureteral catheter placed following a lithotripsy for a stone in the ureter. In caring for the patient immediately after the procedure, the most appropriate nursing action is?

options.text: Milk or strip the catheter every 2 hours.
Measure ureteral urinary drainage every 1 to 2 hours.
Irrigate the catheter with 30-mL sterile saline every 4 hours.
Encourage ambulation to promote urinary peristaltic action.

questions.explanation: Ureteral catheters are small and block easily. Frequent monitoring of output ensures patency. They should generally NOT be irrigated (C) by nurses without specific orders due to small capacity.
questions.hint: Monitor output closely to ensure the tiny tube isn't blocked.

questions.question: The primary difference in the treatment for diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA) and hyperosmolar hyperglycemic syndrome (HHS) is:

options.text: DKA requires administration of bicarbonate to correct acidosis.
Potassium replacement is not necessary in management of HHS.
HHS requires greater fluid replacement to correct the dehydration.
Administration of glucose is withheld in HHS until the blood glucose reaches a normal level.

questions.explanation: HHS typically involves much higher glucose levels and more profound dehydration than DKA because it develops over a longer period. Fluid replacement is the absolute priority in HHS.
questions.hint: HHS patients are often severely dehydrated.

questions.question: The most appropriate nursing intervention for the patient with hyperparathyroidism is:

options.text: Pad side rails as a seizure precaution.
Increase fluid intake to 3000 to 4000 mL daily.
Maintain bed rest to prevent pathologic fractures.
Monitor the patient for Trousseau's and Chvostek's signs.

questions.explanation: Hyperparathyroidism causes Hypercalcemia and kidney stones. High fluid intake dilutes calcium and prevents stone formation. (Seizures/Trousseau's are signs of HYPOcalcemia/Hypoparathyroidism).
questions.hint: Flush the excess calcium out of the kidneys.

questions.question: During the immediate postoperative period following a modified radical mastectomy, the priority exercises a nurse should institute for the affected arm include:

options.text: Have the patient brush or comb her hair with the affected arm.
Perform full passive range-of-motion (ROM) exercises to the affected arm.
Ask the patient to flex and extend the fingers and wrist of the operative side.
Have the patient crawl her fingers up the wall, raising her arm above her head.

questions.explanation: Immediate post-op exercises (first 24h) are limited to hand/wrist movements to maintain circulation without stressing the incision. Full arm movements (A, D) come later.
questions.hint: Start with small distal movements first.

questions.question: An 18-yr-old patient with irregular menstrual periods, hirsutism, and obesity has been diagnosed with polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS). What is an accurate rationale for the expected treatment?

options.text: Hirsutism may be treated with leuprolide to decrease an altered body image.
The medication used will cure the hormonal abnormality of excess testosterone.
The loss of weight will improve all of the symptoms, so this will be the first treatment tried.
The progression of PCOS leads to cardiovascular disease and abnormal insulin resistance if untreated.

questions.explanation: Weight loss is the first-line treatment for obese PCOS patients as it reduces insulin resistance and androgen levels, often restoring ovulation and improving symptoms.
questions.hint: Lifestyle modification is the primary intervention.

questions.question: During neurological examination, the nurse instructs the patient to stand with the feet close together and eyes closed and the patient eventually sways or falls. What findings should the nurse record:

options.text: Positive pronator drift
Absent patellar reflex
Positive Romberg test
Absence of two-point discrimination

questions.explanation: The Romberg test assesses proprioception and vestibular function. Swaying with eyes closed indicates a positive result.
questions.hint: This test checks balance.

questions.question: A patient with an intracranial problem does not open his eyes to any stimulus, has no verbal response except moaning and muttering when stimulated, and flexes his arm in response to painful stimuli. What should the nurse record as the patient's GCS score?
questions.explanation: Eyes: None (1). Verbal: Incomprehensible sounds/moans (2). Motor: Flexion to pain/Decorticate (3). Total = 1+2+3 = 6.
questions.hint: Calculate: E=1, V=2, M=3.

questions.question: The chronic neurologic disorder that involves a deficiency of the neurotransmitters acetylcholine and Î³-aminobutyric acid (GABA) in the basal ganglia and extrapyramidal system is:

options.text: Myasthenia gravis
Parkinson's disease
Huntington's disease
Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS)

questions.explanation: Huntington's disease is characterized by the degeneration of the basal ganglia and a decrease in GABA and Acetylcholine, leading to uncontrolled movements (chorea).
questions.hint: This disease causes chorea (dancing movements).

questions.question: The mode of ventilation used with critically ill patients that allows the patient to self-regulate the rate and depth of spontaneous respirations but may also deliver a preset volume and frequency of breaths is Assist-Control Ventilation (ACV), often referred to as:

options.text: Assist-control ventilation (ACV)
Pressure support ventilation (PSV)
Pressure-controlled inverse ratio ventilation (PC-IRV)
Synchronized intermittent mandatory ventilation (SIMV)

questions.explanation: The question description matches ACV (Assist-Control), where the machine delivers a set breath if the patient initiates, or a mandatory breath if they don't. (Note: The question stem actually names the answer 'Assist-Control Ventilation').
questions.hint: The answer is in the question.

questions.question: The heat related emergency that a healthy athlete with inadequate fluid intake would be most likely to experience after exercise is:

options.text: Heatstroke
Heat attack
Heat cramps
Heat exhaustion

questions.explanation: Heat cramps are painful muscle spasms resulting from salt and fluid loss during exercise, often the first stage of heat illness.
questions.hint: Painful muscle spasms.

questions.question: A young man has drowned in saltwater. What condition will he have that does not occur with freshwater drowning?

options.text: Destruction of surfactant
Noncardiogenic pulmonary edema
Water moves from alveoli to capillary bed and circulation
Fluid is drawn into the alveoli from the pulmonary capillaries

questions.explanation: Saltwater is hypertonic. It draws fluid OUT of the blood into the alveoli (pulmonary edema) via osmosis. Freshwater is hypotonic and moves INTO the blood/circulation.
questions.hint: Salt draws water towards it.

questions.question: Which of the following theorists believed that a person is a biopsychosocial being who is basically good?

options.text: Imogene M. King
Madeline Leininger
Sister Callista Roy
Jean Watson

questions.explanation: Sister Callista Roy's Adaptation Model views the person as an adaptive system (biopsychosocial).
questions.hint: Think of the Adaptation Model.

questions.question: A patient asks the nurse what telangiectasia looks like. Which is the best description for the nurse to give the patient?

options.text: A circumscribed, flat discoloration
Small, superficial, dilated blood vessels
Benign tumor of blood or lymph vessels
Tiny purple spots resulting from tiny hemorrhages

questions.explanation: Telangiectasia (spider veins) are visibly dilated, small superficial blood vessels.
questions.hint: Think 'spider veins'.

questions.question: During the early emergent phase of a burn injury, the patient's laboratory results would likely show the following:

options.text: Increased Hct, decreased serum albumin, decreased serum Na, increased serum K.
Decreased Hct, decreased serum albumin, decreased serum Na, decreased serum K.
Decreased Hct, increased serum albumin, increased serum Na, increased serum K.
Increased Hct, increased serum albumin, decreased serum Na, decreased serum K.

questions.explanation: Emergent phase: Hemoconcentration (High Hct due to fluid loss), Hyperkalemia (cell destruction releases K+), Hyponatremia (Na+ traps in edema/interstitial space), Low Albumin (loss through capillary leak).
questions.hint: Fluid loss makes blood thicker (High Hct) and cells burst (High K).

questions.question: Unlike eukaryotes, prokaryotes have several distinct characteristics that include:

options.text: Mitochondria, golgi bodies, endoplasmic reticulum
Cytoplasmic membrane (cell membrane) with steroids
Nucleus with a classic nuclear membrane
Simple flagellum, capsule and fimbriae

questions.explanation: Prokaryotes (bacteria) lack membrane-bound organelles (nucleus, mitochondria) but often have capsules, fimbriae, and simple flagella.
questions.hint: Prokaryotes are simpler cells without a nucleus.

questions.question: B lymphocytes protect the body through which of the following mechanisms?

options.text: Activating T cells, complement activation, neutralization of pathogen
Inducing inflammation, suppression of immune system, killing of infected cells
Blocking infections, killing infected cells, eliminating microbes
Eliminating reservoirs of infection, complement activation, providing first line defense

questions.explanation: B cells produce antibodies (Humoral immunity). Antibodies neutralize pathogens, activate complement (which lyses bacteria), and opsonize bacteria for phagocytosis.
questions.hint: B cells make antibodies which work with complement.

questions.question: Between the two layers of dura mater are venous sinuses that collects blood from the brain. Which of the following is NOT one of these sinuses?

options.text: Superior sagittal sinus
Transverse sinus
Coronary sinus
Sigmoid sinus

questions.explanation: The coronary sinus collects blood from the heart muscle, not the brain. The others are dural venous sinuses.
questions.hint: One of these is in the heart.

questions.question: You are a novice nurse posted to a new station. During drug administration you accidentally cause a medication error. Arrange the immediate steps you will take to manage the situation:

items.text: Assess the patient immediately for adverse reactions
Document the error in an incident report

questions.explanation: Patient safety is priority (Assessment), followed by medical intervention (Doctor), administrative notification (Manager), and finally documentation.
questions.hint: Patient first, then doctor, then supervisor, then paper.

questions.question: A middle-aged man is brought to the casualty with active nose bleeding. Which finding indicates active bleeding rather than just a history of epistaxis?

options.text: Dried blood in the nostrils
Frequent swallowing
Ecchymosis under the eyes
Deviated septum

questions.explanation: Frequent swallowing indicates blood is dripping down the posterior pharynx, a sign of active posterior epistaxis.
questions.hint: Where does the blood go if not out the nose?

questions.question: You are providing care to a patient following upper abdominal surgery. Select three (3) specific interventions utilized by nurses to prevent acute atelectasis.

options.text: Deep breathing and coughing exercises
Early mobilization/ambulation
Incentive spirometry
Bed rest
Limiting fluid intake

questions.explanation: Expanding the lungs (spirometry, deep breathing) and mobilizing secretions (coughing, ambulation) prevents alveolar collapse (atelectasis).
questions.hint: Interventions that expand the lungs.

questions.question: You are reviewing laboratory results of a patient who is suspected to have developed disseminated intravascular coagulation disorder (DIC) following trauma. Which findings support this diagnosis?

options.text: Decreased Platelet count
Prolonged Prothrombin Time (PT/INR)
Elevated D-Dimer
Increased Fibrinogen
Decreased PTT

questions.explanation: DIC involves consumption of clotting factors. Platelets drop, clotting times (PT/PTT) prolong, and clot breakdown products (D-Dimer) rise. Fibrinogen usually drops.
questions.hint: Clotting factors are used up, so bleeding times increase.

questions.question: You are working in the orthopedic clinic and a patient with fractured radius is brought in for casting. Formulate the PRIORITY nursing diagnosis for this patient.
questions.explanation: Acute Pain is the immediate priority. Risk for Neurovascular Dysfunction (Compartment Syndrome) is the critical safety priority.
questions.hint: Think about what the patient feels and the biggest danger of a cast.

questions.question: Mr. TR is diagnosed with Cushing's syndrome. Select the physical signs you would expect to observe.

options.text: Moon face
Buffalo hump
Truncal obesity
Thin, fragile skin
Thick, oily skin

questions.explanation: Cushing's causes fat redistribution (moon face, hump, truncal obesity) and protein catabolism leading to thin skin and striae.
questions.hint: Think about fat distribution and skin quality.

questions.question: Mrs. MJ stays in a house with very bright light has been diagnosed with Horton's headache (cluster headache). Explain three characteristics of cluster headache.

options.text: Unilateral, severe peri-orbital pain, lacrimation/nasal congestion
Bilateral band-like pressure
Visual aura followed by throbbing pain
Pain worsened by bending forward

questions.explanation: Cluster headaches are severe, unilateral, located around the eye/temple, and associated with autonomic symptoms like tearing (lacrimation) and runny nose.
questions.hint: Pain is one-sided around the eye.

questions.question: Mrs. J, a nurse, is admitted with decompensated cirrhosis (jaundice, ascites, dark urine). Select the appropriate nursing interventions for her care. (Select all that apply)

options.text: Administer diuretics (Spironolactone) to manage ascites
Position in Semi-Fowler's to aid breathing
Restrict sodium and fluid intake
Monitor abdominal girth daily
Encourage high protein diet

questions.explanation: Management involves fluid control (diuretics, restriction, positioning) and monitoring. High protein diet is often restricted if encephalopathy (confusion) is present due to ammonia.
questions.hint: Focus on managing the fluid overload and breathing.
